thread.title: GE Commercial seeks to bankrupt Nathan Tinkler over jet sale
thread.title_full: GE Commercial seeks to bankrupt Nathan Tinkler over jet sale

author: Donna Page
title: GE Commercial seeks to bankrupt Nathan Tinkler over jet sale
text:
GE Commercial Australasia slapped Nathan Tinkler with a bankruptcy notice on June 25. Photo: Nic Walker
High-flying former billionaire Nathan Tinkler is facing bankruptcy over $2.8 million owed from the forced sale of his luxury private jet.
In a week of high drama for the former mining tycoon, it has been revealed GE Commercial Australasia slapped Mr Tinkler with a bankruptcy notice on June 25.
According to Federal Court records, the lender applied for a sequestration order against Mr Tinkler, claiming he owes $US2.3 million which he was ordered to pay by the NSW Supreme Court on May 19.
A former Tinkler staffer said his boss "loved the jet like a child". Photo: Grahame Hutchison
Court documents state that the outstanding amount is now $A2.8 million.
Advertisement Mr Tinkler left the private jet set in November 2012 when GE Australasia appointed Sydney's Taylor Woodings as receiver of TGHA Aviation.
Days later the receiver impounded Mr Tinkler's Dassault Falcon 900C in Singapore and Agusta A109S helicopter in Brisbane.
A former Tinkler staffer said at the time his boss "loved the jet like a child" and "used the helicopter like a taxi".
The bankruptcy case has been listed for a directions hearing in the Federal Court on September 2.
Battling Mr Tinkler is being circled by hostile creditors and on Monday the Adelaide Supreme Court ordered a warrant for his arrest over the liquidation of his Patinack Farm equine empire.
On Thursday, the fallen tycoon dismissed concerns about the collapse of his once vast empire.
Mr Tinkler said that he had made a deal with the Patinack liquidator to pay $700,000, he's given $450,000 and would pay the rest soon.
"At the end of the day I've lost my own money," he said.
"I haven't ripped anyone off, I haven't stolen anything, there never was any warrant and I certainly haven't been concerned at all about this."
Newcastle Herald
